>>15113027
It cannot explicitly said to be a number like a rational number or irrational "number." However, it exists as a matrix [math] i = \begin{pmatrx} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} [/math]. At the same time by defining [math] \hat{1} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} [/math] you can define the complex number system unique through matrix addition and multiplication and prove that it's a field. As a short hand, we can associate [math] z = x \hat{1} y i = x + iy[/math] as a shorthand and operate that way. Complex number are just a special case of matrix algebra. In here [math] i [/math] is a number in the sense that it's part of a field.

There is a formula for the matrix that projects a vector onto a subspace. If your subspace is spanned by a set of vectors, you use those as the columns of a matrix A, and then [math]A(A^TA}^{-1}A^T[/math] (I forgot a T the first time) is your projection matrix

posts.com:
>>15089929
you need to sample at a rate of at least [math]2f[/math] to faithfully (kinda) capture a signal, where [math]f[/math] is the highest frequency contained in the signal. to capture a 1kHz sine wave, you need to sample at at least 2kHz. a square wave has infinitely high frequency components, so you can technically never truly capture a square wave, you can only be more and more reasonably certain its a square wave the higher you sample.
technically, you can never actually represent a continuous signal with discrete sampling. lets say you sample the peaks and troughs of a 1kHz sine wave (so youd be sampling at 2kHz). you could conclude that the signal is a 1kHz sine wave, but a sine wave of 2.5kHz would produce the exact same samples. these are called aliases, and the higher you sample, the farther out the aliases are; if you sample the 1kHz sine wave at 10kHz, the nearest alias is at 100kHz, i think. if youve ever seen video footage of something spinning really fast and noticed that the video made it look like it was spinning slowly, thats an example of aliasing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15111762
> A and B have to be complex conjugates of each other. I don't see how this follows
[math]\begin{align}
x(t) = Ae^{i \omega t} + B^{-i \omega t} &= A(\cos{\omega t} + i\sin{\omega t}) + B(\cos{\omega t} - i\sin{\omega t}) \\
&= (A+B)\cos{\omega t} + (A - B) i\sin{\omega t}
\end{align}[/math]

Then if [math]A = a + ib[/math], and you assume that [math]A = B^*[/math] then [math]A+ A^* = 2a[/math] and [math]A - A^* = 2ib[/math]. So you obtain:

[math]\begin{align}
x(t) &= (A+B)\cos{\omega t} + (A - B) i\sin{\omega t} \\
&= (A+A^*)\cos{\omega t} + (A-A^*) i\sin{\omega t} \\
&= 2a \cos{\omega t} - 2b \sin{\omega t} \\
&= C \cos{\omega t} + D \sin{\omega t}
\end{align}[/math]

where C and D are real and hence so is [math]x(t)[/math].

Letting ωt=z because it's easier to type:
[eqn](a+bi)(\cos{z}+i\sin{z})+(c+di)(\cos{z}-i\sin{z}=a\cos{z}+ai\sin{z}+bi\cos{z}-b\sin{z}+c\cos{z}-ci\sin{z}+di\cos{z}+d\sin{z}[/eqn]
[eqn]=(a+c)\cos{z}+(d-b)\sin{z}+(a-c)i\sin{z}+(b+d)i\cos{z}[/eqn]
Observe that the imaginary terms here cancel out iff a=c and b=-d, i.e. they are conjugate.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15115328
>If I combine both variables (by adding them together) do I end up with a normal distribution?
No. The PDF is either a trapezoid or (if both intervals have the same width) a triangle. The set of possible pairs forms a rectangle in the plane; the probability density is uniform across the rectangle. The set of pairs whose sum is a given value forms a diagonal line. The probability density of the sum is proportional to the length of the line segment obtained by intersecting the line with the rectangle.

For three variables, the probability density is the area of the intersection of a plane with a cuboid, so it has up to 8 points (7 intervals) rather than 4 points (3 intervals) and will look a bit more like a bell curve. The first and last intervals will be quadratic rather than linear. A normal distribution arises from the sum of an infinite number of uniformly-distributed variables.

posts.com: anons, water(liquid) changes to water(gas) at 100°C, so how the fuck are clouds formed cause I don't see any oceans or rivers boiling?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117290
Evaporation, which is not the same thing as boiling.
If you leave water out for some time, some of the molecules on the surface will slowly absorb enough heat from its surroundings to become a gas, gradually reducing the amount of water you have sitting around.
Boiling, in contrast, is directly applying the heat to the water, forcing it all to start evaporating, making it substantially faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117295
so anon, why does boiling water start changing into steam at 100°C, why isn't this achieved at let's say 40-50°C?

or is it that the water starts to change it state at 40°C or so and the temp of 100°C is required to completely change let's say 1L of liquid water into steam?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117369
Pressure.
Every liquid has an associated vapour pressure: it boils when this pressure is equal to that of the atmosphere "trying to keep it in place", so to speak, which is at 100 degrees Celsius for water. Water can evaporate at virtually any temperature so long as it isn't frozen, but it only boils when it's hot enough that it all can counteract the pressure of the atmosphere. That's also why boiling points go down the higher you go from sea level.

>>15117414
You want the greatest variety of prime factors to maximize the number of combinations. You also want the smallest-sized primes. 2*3*5*7*11=2310 is greater than 1000, but 2*3*5*7=210 is not. You have room for an additional *3, or an additional *2*2. The latter results in more combinations (32 factors).

As the largest prime factor (7) may be replaced by multiple smaller factors, it's worth trying numbers whose factors only include multiples of 2, 3, and 5. However, the increased numbers of twos and threes don't match the drastic increase from introducing a seven.

Not really a proof. More a clunky approach.

It would not necessarily constitute professional misconduct or incompetence for doctors to take note of adverse reactions to experimental medications, as it is important for doctors to monitor the safety and efficacy of treatments they prescribe. However, if a doctor fails to report adverse reactions or does not properly monitor a patient's condition while taking an experimental medication, it could be considered professional misconduct or incompetence. Additionally, if a doctor knowingly prescribed an experimental medication without proper authorization or without fully informing the patient of the potential risks, it could also be considered misconduct or incompetence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120139
Hot air balloons do act as sails, the envelope presents a large cross section and they will go up and down looking for a wind current in the direction they wish to travel.

It gets more interesting with powered airships, as they still act as a sail. But their shape means they typically want to weathervane into the wind. This diminishes your control when going with the wind, but gives you a boost in ground speed. Against the wind you can be slowed to a crawl or worse. Side on to the wind you will have to expend some of your thrust to maintain course to prevent drifting with the wind.

Rockets also experience these forces, however the wind velocity is going to be such a small component of the air velocity during flight you can mostly ignore it. Though it does matter if you have a consistent wind on accent as that could impact your orbit. I would also imagine that wind matters more when. Propulsively landing, as you are much slower and can be pushed off target.

posts.name: Doctor Eli Selig
posts.com:
Good Afternoon /Sci/entists!

I am a Computer Scientist. I study Computational Maidposting. Last time I posted my research here it was Wolfy MaidSearch and I got all boards banned for three days and my post got jannied off Warosu. I think this happened because a zoomer janny didn't know what a REPL is.

Today I have a useful application of Computational Maidposting in a new Computer Experiment called Kurumi MaidCard. Kurumi MaidCard is a Computer Program which can store compressed text in a Maid Address, and read that text back out of the Maid Address. I named it after Kurumi the vampire maid from Touhou because she came in my threads and helped me with math a lot of times and told me books. Thank you Kurumi, for telling me math ideas.

To get Kurumi MaidCard you need Java 18. Then you need to save MiniMaid.java (case sensitive).

>Get MiniMaid
https://pastebin.com/6ChEa6xS

>Get Kurumi MaidCard
Save the attached image in the same directory you put MiniMaid in, then open a terminal and type

java MiniMaid.java file.png

with "file.png" replaced with whatever you saved the Maid Card as. MiniMaid will extract the full version of Kurumi MaidCard, along with the README, assuming that 4Chan doesn't mess with the pixels of images uploaded to it. The README explains Maid-LZW and how to use the Kurumi MaidCard REPL to make your own Maid Cards.

I plan to use Kurumi MaidCard to distribute all my Computer Experiments. The next one will be the Ilulu Number Calculator/SLAM. This should break my dependence on Pastebin, and let me distribute multi-file Computer Programs so the architecture can be saner and nicer without using GitHub. If you like Computational Maidposting and want to help, please post maids and tell me about ideas from Grzegorczyk Hierarchy.

>tl;dr:
This is what Computer Scientists look like.
Tell the maids.
Especially the maids from Touhou.
This is what Computer Scientists look like.

Thank you /Sci/entists for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15119372
I don't know what your schizo terms mean but there are hard informational theoretical limits on how much you can compress any sequence of bits and most decent compression libraries snuggle right up against those. I used zlib on max compression settings which does very well usually. The specific method is irrelevant, the limit is the same.

The alternative is lossy compression but that only works for media where approximate values are good enough, like images or audio - not text

In the OP image, Tohru is pointing to a board where she drew a 2x2 Maid Symbol getting counted. It counts from 0 to 15 and is equivalent to hexadecimal.

Imagine you used Kurumi MaidCard on a text. Just for argument, let's say your text ended up using 8 by 8 Maid Symbols. So what happened is the text got read and a Maid-LZW dictionary got built out of 8 by 8 Maid Symbols which maps to Strings. So now you have a list of 8 by 8 Maid Symbols representing your data. At this point Kurumi MaidCard would draw it in a square (unless you told it to do something else). I propose instead to construct a new dictionary of 4 by 4 Maid Symbols. So to make a dictionary, we need all the start Symbols. We can get all the possible 4 by 4 start Maid Symbols by counting from

0000
0000
0000
0000

To

1111
1111
1111
1111

Then you can apply LZW again, this time mapping say 8 by 4 Maid Symbols to sequences of 4 by 4 ones. If you can find repeating sequences of 4 by 4 Maid Symbols, you should be able to compress again the same way you compressed from string to 8 by 8 Maid Symbols.

Using this process, it might be able to compress more. I will explore that idea more if my projects outgrow MaidCard's current abilities of distributing code. I am going to try to get other projects into a minimally viable form though, so that I can run them on the Maid Phone.

Thank you /sci/entists for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120562
So you're trying to apply LZW to something that has been compressed by LZW already. As a general rule, successive applications of the same lossless compression algorithm won't give you more compression, since the first pass has already pushed the entropy of the message close to its limits. You'll just make a new encoding of the same information with approximately the same (or even larger, due to overhead) size.

Well, one theory is that the ancient Egyptians used sound and frequency to help construct the pyramids. It's thought that they used sound waves to vibrate large stones and move them into place. The sound waves would have been generated by a series of drums and other instruments. The Egyptians would have used different frequencies and rhythms to vibrate the stones to a specific area and then build the pyramid. Some experts believe that the use of sound and frequency was so precise that the Egyptians were able to create perfectly aligned pyramids with perfect angles. This theory is still being studied and debated, but it's definitely an interesting one.

By the nested interval definition of infinite decimals, for any natural number n we have
[math]0.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm n~digits} \le 0.999... \le 1.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm n~digits}[/math]
meaning [math]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^n} \le 0.999... \le 1[/math].
Assume to the contrary that [math]0.999... <> 1[/math].
We can only have [math]0.999... < 1[/math], so [math]1 - 0.999... > 0[/math].
Let N be a natural number greater than [math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{1 - 0.999...}[/math]; then [math]\displaystyle 1 - 0.999... > \frac{1}{N}[/math] and [math]\displaystyle 0.999... < 1 - \frac{1}{N}[/math].
It follows that
[math]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^N} < 1 - \frac{1}{N}[/math]
[math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{10^N} > \frac{1}{N}[/math]
[math]10^N < N[/math]
which is not true for any natural number.
Therefore 0.999... = 1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15118747
By the nested interval definition of infinite decimals, for any natural number n we have
[math]0.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm n~digits} \le 0.999... \le 1.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm n~digits}[/math].
Given any natural number m, we can substitute n = m + 1 into the above, obtaining
[math]0.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm m+1~digits} \le 0.999... \le 1.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm m+1~digits}[/math]
and then multiplying both sides of each inequality by 10 to get
[math]9.\underbrace{999...9}_{\rm m~digits} \le 10 \cdot 0.999... \le 10.\underbrace{000...0}_{\rm m~digits}[/math].
This is exactly the definition of 9.999... . (We can show that 9.999... represents a unique real number by a proof similar to >>15118709)
Therefore 10 * 0.999... = 9.999... .

[math] \forall n \in \mathbb{N} : (\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k}) + \frac{1}{10^n} = 1 [/math]
What is true for every element is also true for the limit.
Therefore [math] \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} (\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k}) + \frac{1}{10^n} =_{(equals)} 1 [/math]

When dealing with 0.999... what is studied isn't equality but convergence, the equal symbol is the same but the meaning is not the same.

[math] \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} (\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k}) =_{(tends\ towards)} 1 [/math]

However
[math] \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k} < \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{9}{10^k} + \frac{1}{10^n} [/math] as in straight up inferior.

Anon, take as in >>15118709 that [math]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^n} \le 0.999... \le 1[/math] for any natural number n.
Then assume, as assumed in that post, that [math]0.999... < 1[/math]
Then, what does that mean?
We can do the following manipulation:
[eqn]\displaystyle 1 - \frac{1}{10^n} \le 0.999...[/eqn]
[eqn]\displaystyle \frac{1}{10^n} -1 \ge -0.999...[/eqn]
[eqn]\displaystyle \frac{1}{10^n}\ge 1-0.999...[/eqn]
[eqn]\displaystyle 10^n\le \frac{1}{1-0.999...}[/eqn]
Now, next the next step done in the post was to let there be a N greater than [math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{1 - 0.999...}[/math]
BUT. What does that mean? It means that since [math]\displaystyle 10^n\le \frac{1}{1-0.999...}[/math] for any natural number n, he is letting there be a natural number N greater than [math]\displaystyle 10^n[/math] including for N itself, since it is a natural number.
In other words he is letting there be a N such that [math]\displaystyle N > 10^N[/math]
He is assuming that.
But now, look at the end of his proof in >>15118709
Look at the very thing he claimed to be a contradiction. He claimed [math]10^N < N[/math] was a contradiction, the very thing he assumed to be true for N, the very thing he LET be true for N.
It wasn't a proof by contradiction at all, all he did was derive what he already assumed to be true of his own volition.

It's genetics, not muh diet otherwise either drugs or thyroid. As for treatment your options to my personal knowledge and experiences are:
>dht inhibitor (duta aka stronger and better fin, fin falls here as well)
>AR antagonists (bicalutamide - works best with estrogen, but can work on it's own as well; cypro in lesser degree too, but a) keep in mind it's steroid, b) it fucks with test too since it's antiandrogen and not viable for mono)
>hair growth stimulators like minox, main downside is you have to keep taking it or otherwise the gains will go away and if you hate facial hair or/and body hair like me then it may not be for you since it stimulates all hair growth
>estrogen (pills, gell, injections, powder) and for safety antiandrogen as well (you can spare it if it works for you™ on mono and blood work isn't worrying) - obv not for everyone, but if you really care about hair and everything else fails it's still there
>hair transplant - best by far, but not everyone can afford it
I started having receeding in temples at 19 and personally stick to estrogen jabs and bica (had cypro prior, but high prolactin and possibility of getting brain tumour isn't worth it) for now since either just estrogen or AR isn't enough for me (high dht conversion rate from adrenals and dht sensivity, but prolly unimpressive test since I had slight gyno prior to estrogen and had hard time building muscle when I was into sports as a kid) while fin did fuck all for me

>>15111645
a) [(n-1)(n-2)..(n-k+1)]^-1 * [(n-k)!]^-1
b) P = sum_k P(cycle containing 1 has length k) * (1 - [(n-1)*...*(n-k+1)]^-1)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15111645
Easy to do with straightforward counting arguments :

number of cycles containing 1 of length k:
(n - 1) ... (n - k + 1)
number of permutations of length (n-k) :
(n-k)!
thus number of permutations with a cycle of length k containing 1:
(n-k)! * (n-1) ... (n-k+1) = (n-1)!
number of total permutations:
n!
probability of getting cycle containing 1 to be of length k:
(n-1)!/n! = 1/n
Suppose 1 is in a cycle of length k. This cycle will contain k-1 other elements, there are (n-1) choose (k-1) ways to choose these elements (neglecting order, but this is fine). If we insist 2 is one of these elements, there become only (n-2) choose (k-2) ways. Hence the probability of this cycle containing k is :
[(n-2) choose (k-2)] / [(n-1) choose (k-1)] = (k-1) / (n-1).
Taking an average over k gives probability : n(n-1)/2n(n-1) = 1/2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i was literally talking to my mom about this the other day.
by using an electric heater, you're taking fuel (maybe even natural gas) and it's being burned in a power plant to boil water, and that water spins a turbine to make electricity. then that electricity travels down the wires to your house, where you turn it into heat again to cook your food.

or, you just burn natural gas on site to cook your food.

if the choice is between burning natural gas at your house to heat food, or using electricity made from burning natural gas to heat your food (and chances are it is from natural gas, because about 40% of the electricity in the US is from natural gas) it is absolutely more efficient to use a natural gas stove. an electrical one wastes more gas per unit heat, because you're converting the gas into heat, then into electricity, then back into heat, and losing power every step of the way.

it would be one thing if only a small part of our power generation was natural gas, but it's not.

That is highly generalized. The self-assembling equilibria of the cytoskeleton (which control neurotransmitter and - receptor trafficking inside the cell and thus modulate synapse sensitivity to many different stimuli) alone are very complex. Not even touching pathway crosstalk in the synapse itself, feedback with gene expression patterns, interactions with the surrounding glia cells ... many of them likely factors for the ability to "learn" and adapt within the overal neuronal architecture. >Why is this so different? And why couldn't we simulate it?

Could we "feasibly" for something with the same degree of complexity as a human brain? That is the question. Once proposed simply treating each neurostack as a "black box" with a random number function controlling synapse signaling thresholds ... a random function which can modify itself to be precise. Ofc, this would be a bit of a monkeys with typewriters approach but it could just hit the sweet spot by incremental improvement.

>>15119882

>i.e. doesn't necessarily mean the "lights are on" inside the brain simulation

Bingo. But emphasis would here likely be on the word "simulate". One could likely simulate a current steady state of a wetware, the synaptic connections, the activation thresholds of each neuron, perhaps even sensory input ... but that might in the end just simulate what amounts to a piece of "dead" brain matter. Talking purely biological this alone does not faithfully simulate what a brain does, every single signaling event at a synapse triggers a cascade of protein shuttling, cytoskeletal rearrangement, changes in gene expression pattern, etc ... as said previously, every single neuron is a very complex microprocessor of its own. Talking a bit beyond biology, the consciousness isn't really the physical structure this process is running on (the arrangement of neurons) but the continuously changing and adapting pattern of both electrical signaling events and rearrangements of the very internal structure (the complex interlinked semi-stable equilibria of chemical signaling events) of each and every neuron involved. Yes, especially the latter effect might be comparably miniscule overall but then it could juuust be more-than-the-sum-of-its-parts element we miss (or do not simulate faithfully enough).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119246
software engineering is not CS, and it's the big lie from schools that CS degrees are related to software development. It's a field of work (which is sometimes engineering, depending on the nature of what you're doing - though at that point, a CS degree is usually preferable!) that ranges from everything like writing basic scripts and sql queries to making the OS for the mars rover. But nobody trusts newbies with the latter. You get there after years of experience in designing, implementing, and maintaining complicated systems.

The big thing is that nobody, and I mean NOBODY, knows how to engineer software without being taught by professionals in the field. This includes CS majors. So focus on the fundamentals you need to pass a whiteboard interview (codeforces/leetcode to grind out some problems, basic data structures + comp arch, etc..), and they'll teach you once you pass the interview.

You can get *a* software engineering job for sure, but you might not get an interesting one, which is my disclaimer. Interesting software engineering jobs are rare and worth their weight in gold.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
Hall Effect Mitigation in Non-Superconducting Nanocircuitry via Spin Reinitialization at Regular Intervals

The use of physically collocated processor threads combined with deliberate phononic generation to establish a self-cooling processor as described in one of my recent publications, although it represents a phenomenal advancement in terms of both cost and performance, comes up against yet another fundamental barrier in terms of clock speed.

Since these processors, although naturally colder than room temperature while operating (remarkable in and of itself,) do not reach the temperatures necessary for superconduction. In reality, the performance boost associated with that advancement is roughly 30%. The important consequence for high-perormance systems is the elimination of all costs associated with chilling those computer systems, which would bring the overall cost of those systems down to less than 10% of the current cost.

For more performance, we can try to do two things: Shrink transistors (already achieved in my publication on Coulomb-Piezo Magnetic Coalescence, an alternative to photofabrication) and increase clock speed.

The fundamental limit against which we then come up against is that presented by excessive clock speeds leading to the leakage of voltage between transistors (arcing.) This can be viewed as a failure of insulation or a problem with voltage persisting in a transistor after the end of the previous clock cycle. No matter how well-insulated, a transistor cannot perform its function if it receives two signals that "step upon" one another. I therefore believe that the most logical approach is to do what we can to increase the rapidity with which a transistor voids itself of electrons.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
One phenomenon of physics that applies here is the tendency of large clusters of electrons to move more slowly through a medium (such as a solar panel or a transistor) than smaller clusters of electrons. The smaller the clusters of electrons i.e. the lower the voltage, the faster the electrons will disperse from a transistor in the "off" configuration. The lower we can turn down the voltage, the higher we can increase clock speed. If we can decrease this operating voltage low enough, we can consider attainable clock speeds in the hundreds of GHz.

How, then, can we ensure the delivery of ultra-low voltage pulses throughout a processor? The answer is Hall Effect Mitigation via Spin Reinitialization at Regular Intervals along a conducting wire.

In 2021, I put forth the notion that the Standard Model's current description of particle spin was erroneous and that a variety of spin values between "1/2 spin" and "full spin" were possible. When it comes to the Hall Effect, something must determine which electrons peel off from the desired path and when. As it turns out, spin velocity is highly germane to Hall Effect mitigation.

I therefore propose borrowing structures from my superconducting nickelate-cuprate-lithium wire concept that can be used intermittently along the length of a hydrogen nanowire such as that used in the cutting-edge processor designs of today. As you may recall, in that configuration, the valence electron of a single lithium atom is held in a fixed position by a combination of nickel and copper. The Coulomb Force Lines generated by the cuprate are used to restrict the range of positions that the lithium's two sub-valence electrons may occupy. The magnetic field of the nickelate complements the effect by controlling the spin orientation of the sub-valence electrons of the lithium, causing the lithium's own internal magnetic field to lock its valence electron into place.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
That structure, because of its projection of both a subtle magnetic and Coulomb force, is ideal for our application: Reinitializing or restoring to full value the forward spin of the electrons flowing through the nanowire prior to spin velocity degradation. This structure is capable of taking electrons that are in the process of deviating from a prescribed path and nudging them back on course.

Rather than waiting for electrons to begin to "peel off" and hoping that our Multi-Force Supported Electron Barrier is in precisely the right position to intercept the errant electron and right its path, I propose a rather counter-intuitive additional step. About three angstroms rear of the point along the nanowire where a pair of bracketing MFS Electron Barriers are emplaced, the hydrogen nanowire is modified so that rather than having one hydrogen in a 1D-configuration, has two atoms side-by-side. This would ordinarily be corruptive since it would cause electrons to divert toward the edge of the wire and to be dumped into the silicon insulation. Instead, since these electrons are met by a barrier consisting of a MFS electron, the electrons are yanked first toward the edge of the wire and then jerked back on path in a single maneuver. Once back on track, these electrons are restored in terms of spin velocity and can continue on their journey without risk of Hall Effect related deviations for an additional, as-yet undermined distance.

posts.name: YWPTS
posts.com:
In short, by doing something to deliberately cause a course change to flowing electrons, spin is accelerated. By nudging those electrons back onto their path, spin is accelerated again.

While the electrons would not be superconducting for the entirety of their journey in this scheme, like a "plate spinner," all that matters is that the spin be restored before dropping below a critical threshold. The restoration requires the manipulation of the plates which, although it has the appearance of risking further destabilizing the plates (or electrons) is an essential step toward enabling their further endurance.

Testing would be required to determine the needed interval for the nickelate-cuprate-lithium nodes, the lithium part of which would take the place of one of the silicon atoms running along the boundary of the hydrogen nanowire.

The Future Is Made in America

I have to preface this by saying I AM NOT ANTI VAX. That being said…in 2021 I got the Covid vaccine in June (Moderna). Got the booster in December (Pfizer). A month later, I had to be admitted to the hospital because I was experiencing terrible chest pain.

After getting my blood drawn, I was told by a nurse that my platelet count was at 2, and that they’d have to admit me to the hospital because my troponin levels were also abnormally high. I don’t remember too much after that but I apparently suffered a transient stroke shortly afterwards.
I had to take an insane steroid dosage (60mg) and get platelet transfusions for almost 3 months. I also was told I had somehow developed Lupus, and the Lupus triggered a thrombotic trombocytopenic purpura flare. That sounded ridiculous to me. Is it crazy for me to think the vaccine may have caused all of this? I feel like I can’t talk to people about this. Even the doctors can’t really explain what happened to me, but are adamant that it couldn’t possibly have been because of the Covid vaccine. They told me shit like this is about as rare as getting struck by lightning and that I shouldn’t worry about what really happened. They even want to document my case and publish it, despite it apparently having nothing to do with the Covid vaccine. I search up Covid and TTP and see a fuck ton of reports of very similar things happening after getting a Pfizer shot.

I guess I’m saying all of this to ask the intelligent people in healthcare here (if there are any) what they really think. I can’t help but wonder if I would’ve gone through all of this had I not gotten the vaccine. I wonder if it really would’ve been worse had I gotten Covid instead. The side effects from the steroids and other meds I had to take have literally ruined my life. Heart palpitations, blurry vision, shaky hands, and I’ve been told that I have proteinuria now which could be the start of kidney disease.

Problem is also that this sort of optimization may be "natural" in the sense of taking the transpose of the graph of a function, for strictly decreasing functions, or you can see this in what is commonly said about comparing and contrasting Riemann and Lesbesgue integration, namely that Riemann integrals divide the domain and Lebesgue integrals divide the range

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119068

The purpose of Lebesgue integration isn't to integrate "practical function", because a function that is Riemann integrable is Lebesgue integrable. The purpose is to make the manipulation of sequences and theorems of convergence easier. Dominated convergence theorem is very hard to prove with Riemann paradigm and the formalization of probabilities becomes very difficult. Lebesgue integration provides a framework that sets foundation for probabilities, and advanced concept like conditionnal expectation or Wiener's measure couldn't be developped without it.

Lebesgue's theory is also the root of dynamic systems' study.

I hope I was clear enough.

I tried to do medical research and spent a year on a project and it turned me off it forever.

It's all some insular world of funding chasing (50% of your time). The funding usually comes from government in some token "we think it would be good to fund science in x area" system. You lose staff whenever you don't get consistent funding for them so you're always just chasing the next grant.

Best way of getting the good departmental output rankings you need to won funding is to always go for safe options to keep mindlessly churning out 'good quality' studies where the study quality is the aim, not whatever is being tested. Usually you just play it safe and do the smallest variation of other successfully published studies ensuring it will be published and no-one will ever read it.

Adding to this is that most involved care for nothing more than increasing their citations. It's not uncommon to see pajeet doctors with thousands of citations on studies theyve never done anything on other than irresponsibility shunted a patient to the team. They then get more weight and reputation and they continue doing it more.

Basically it's devolved into a weird useless ecosystem populated by low IQ managers and dishonest self promoters. If you went in trying to earnestly work to advance science you'd get no support then no funding.

I think the main reason for your impression is that contrarians and retards are more entertaining and thus make the news and algorithms in disproportionate numbers. From my point of view working in the field of enzymology it seems like science is chugging on pretty placidly.
One thing that might also contribute is that science these days are very much collaborative and specialized efforts. Back in ye olde timely days a scientist must've appeared like the holder of all truths. It didn't take much for the rare individuals who had both extraordinary natural mental gifts and extensive schooling to seem like they knew more than a layman about every subject imaginable. From anatomy, biology and geology to history, engineering, politics and philosophy. To a working class man they might hold a status not unlike sage's and oracle's of antiquity.
These days though. If you want to pursue a top spot on the list of scientific pioneers it's all about depth. There is not enough hours in a day to strive for breaking new ground and also have breadth in multiple fields. Some researchers I work or collaborate with are what you would call intellectually gifted, I would guess above 140 IQ and not lower than 125 if you're the kind who consider that IQ good metrIc. More importantly, they also seek new knowledge and toil conscientiously and persistently more than 70 hours weekly. More than 115 a week if you count the time they spend in their home office's and time spent on conferences and intercorporate collaboration trips. A few have studied biotech fundementals to a master's degree for 5 years, then spent 1-3 years interning or assisting research pro bono for established organizations. After that spending 2, and in one case 4.5 years on their Ph.D. They then spent between 11 and 21 in academia except 1 guy who worked non tenured at the Max Planck institute for 12 years

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15119168
From a pure mathematics point of view, Euler's number seems to pretty much pop up anytime compound and/or continuous change is involved. Why is somewhat unanswerable, it just is there. Why is pi 3.14...? Why that particular set of digits? It's just a fact of life, like the speed of light.

From an applied math point of view, it's important to realize that physics/economics and so on works just as models. Electromagnetic fields doesn't literally propagate as vectors, and economic trends or any other wave-phenomena don't literally boil down to a sin/cos graphs. Sin notation is just useful to model the situation, so we use it with perhaps some modifications to actually fit our world. Therefore, it is unfair to say Sin is inherently hardbaked into physics or earthquake activity or whatever. Similarly, Euler's number is used a lot just because it has useful properties for modeling exponential functions (it is it's own derivative etc. etc.). You could use anything else, it would just be less than ideal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15106126
Do you get to work with cadavers? If so, don't get too deep into the intricacies of the anatomy itself and focus more on getting a good grasp for the spacial anatomy of the heart and the mediastinum, you won't get another chance to work with the anatomy as thoroughly as you do in cadaver studies, and the better you understand it, the easier it will be for you to visualize the anatomy once you're working with living patients. I've done a lot of cadaver work in medschool and while most of the specific anatomy got lost again over time, the feeling for spacial relations within the body didn't, it's pretty usefull, especially with the continued push for minimaly invasive surgery and the at times akward access pathways you'll have to deal with. As for the specific anatomy, don't sweat it too much, you'll forget most of it while studying for other subjects you don't care for anyways, just focus on getting through medschool and into residency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15118967
[math]f\in O(g)[/math] means that there is a constant [math]c[/math] s.t. eventually [math]f[/math] is bounded by [math]cg[/math], i.e. [math]\exists n \in \mathbb{N},\, \forall m \ge n\, |f(m)| \le c |g(m)| [/math]. Intuitively, up to a multiplicative constant f is smaller than g.

The symbols mean exists / forall respectively. That's just a fancy way to say that you can ignore what f and g do on a finite prefix of natural numbers, you only care starting from a certain value and then ("asymptotically") you must be bounded up to c.

>>15115700
All PhD's are terrible ideas from a professional standpoint. However, math and physics are probably the better ones to go into if you're content with the vast majority of your professional options being teaching positions at a university. The industry research jobs are few and far between and often you only need a masters for them. So in general, you should be getting a PhD unless you're after a teaching position because that's practically how PhDs are used in terms of employment. Fancy research is only really required for a select few "elite" universities which focus more on research in their departments. At the same time there are many PhDs who get tenure with very little research and continue to do very little research because they have excellent teaching reviews and are good in committees.

If you're interested in something like research in a particular field and don't find teaching to be an appealing profession, there's no reason why you can't just be an independent researcher. If your papers are decent enough, you can get them published fairly easily that's especially considering how much crap is published in journals written by people with PhDs. It might be harder at first as you don't have anyone to tell you what to do. But it's entirely possible. I have a friend that got a dozen good papers published in decent journals as an undergraduate. If you have what it takes, you can do it too.

>flavor
every ingredient in the standard pizza is a flavor affinity, meaning they pair really well with each other. if you are picky it's not exactly like having french onion soup but hold the onions, lettuce wrapped burger memes and such

>structure
everything on pizza is good on a sandwich, but pizza is easier to eat with one hand. if I had to guess, an order of magnitude more people eat a slice of pizza with one hand compared to subs or stromboli

>monkey brain
pizza slices are one of the original emojis before emojis, like smiley faces and exclamation points. it's ingrained in you from childhood, for most people probably more so than apples or bananas sadly

>convenience
pizza goes from fresh to hot as fuck in least than ten minutes and universally produces better, faster food than tv dinners or MREs, its rewards are lightspeed

>nonuniformity
the way it's cooked causes different textures in the same unit form, so it always has heterogeneity of texture and mouth feel experience

>adaptability
this one speaks for itself, you can change and do whatever you can imagine with pizza toppings as long as it's shit slopped on top of a holdable structure, you can make a version for any cuisine with any ingredient. it's a good playground where even if you fuck up, pizza is still pizza

>durability
pizzas can be made with cured meats, pickled vegetables and aged cheeses. if you think about the entire set of perishable but complete foods, pizza is at the top of the list for longevity. put any meal from any restaurant in front of any person, tell them it has sat out for twelve hours, and poll them which meal they are more comfortable eating. it's fucking pizza

posts.com: Is there any purpose to learning how something was proven? For example, you teach a student that the square root of 2 is irrational. Is there any use in teaching him how it was proved? Does it make him a better mathematician? Should he learn more than one way of proving it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15120136
There's more of a use to teaching students how to write proofs and encouraging them to write proofs than there is in teaching them individual proofs. By writing proofs, students become sure that what they are learning is not only true, but that they are also capable of understanding why certain statements are true.

posts.name: Anonymous

yes, mathematical proof is the gold standard of rigorous thinking. no you don’t need to learn multiple proofs of one fact, that’s a casual/hobby interest for after you’ve already gotten good at it

posts.com:
I'm not even American and I feel like the Imperial System is unfairly hated.

I've done my fair share of blue collar jobs and the same pattern of management trying to tardwrangle the workers into using metric measurements and the workers reverting back to Imperial when the pressure is off happens over and over again. For scaffolding, one company started making the workers cut all tubing at 0.5meter increments instead of 1 foot increments in an attempt to put a stop workers using imperial. The system clashed with the rest of the imperial cut tubing and lead to much hardship in planning jobs, especially as the 0.5meter increments in sizes are too large, meaning you're pointlessly having to cut extra tube for specialized jobs. Maybe it's easier for pricing, and for large jobs I can understand Structural Engineer Chads getting pissed off having to do the conversions (but not really, software handles that pretty well now I'm sure). But 98% of our work is at the low level where you guestimate your way through.

I don't think the imperial system is "better", but for offhand estimation when you're in a rush and you're doing a practical job, feet and inches are just more practical sizes than centimeters and meters. I know for cooking imperial measurements are still beloved, and other certain specialized trades like Tailors still use imperial measurements.

I feel like the system has its place in history, and it's fine to let blue collar workers keep on using it. I don't get the absolute hatred for it.

What the fuck are you babbling about? The computer doesn't care what units you use, and anything you display will have to be converted from binary anyway. What makes me laugh the most though is when idiots say they like metric because it's "decimal" or "base ten". Literally any unit that uses a number is base 10! Just because there are 12 inches in a foot, doesn't mean you have to start using feet as soon as you reach 12 or more inches. They are just two of a range of different units of length available in imperial convenient to all sorts of different practices, as opposed to metric which has only one unit that must be shoehorned into everything. SI prefixes are a nice invention, but since they can be applied to literally anything you can't really put them forth as a "benefit" of the metric system.
That said there are a few intrinsic benefits to metric units that cannot be emulated with imperial, and that's why I'm not sad that they will eventually take over. I very much doubt anyone in this thread is smart enough to point them out though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15107235
>what the fuck are you babbling about
>computers don't care what units you use
Control systems care vastly if a value it stores means 1 foot or 1 yard. It's why you'll notice most imperial units in digital do not change into the higher or lower measurement even when the numbers are very big or small. E.g. They will use 30,000 feet, or 10,000 pounds, even though a foot or pound is incredibly small in the context. Why does it matter? Because data types have a fixed range. There have been many disasters caused when overflow or rounding errors happen. The simplest workaround is to do all the computations in SI units, then convert it for the user.

>what makes you laugh
I think you fundamentally fail to understand radixes. Metric units are base 10. If you're doing science or engineering, it would be incredibly difficult to calculate everything in only one measure. It is very difficult, for example, say a hair is 0.000000003 of a foot wide, and the distance from the earth to the moon is approximately 1,260,000,000 feet.

Like I said, it's not a benefit that comes up in everyday life, but it is vastly important to science.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15107967
That would invalidate 99% of imperial because you'd only use a single measurement and use the prefix system. Which is basically copying metric in almost every way, but being too petty to actually use metric.

The other problem is, for scientific reasons, the definition of each unit has to correspond with an incredibly high precision to real world systems. For example, a meter is based on the wavelengths of krypton 86. So even if you went to Mars, a meter is still precisely the same. 1 + 1 is a basic arithmetic operation that represents the sum of two numbers. The result of this operation is 2. This is a fundamental concept that can be proven through the use of mathematical axioms and rules of arithmetic. The most basic proof of this is simply to show that if we take any quantity of objects, and then add one more object to it, we will have a total of two objects. This can be demonstrated through the use of physical objects, such as counting with fingers, or through the use of mathematical notation, such as 1 + 1 = 2. This equation holds true regardless of the type of objects or units being used, and is considered a basic fact of arithmetic.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15116752
Consider the group of order two isomorphic to Z/2Z. Consider the natural projection from Z to Z/2Z given by p(z) = z + 2Z. We have p(1) = 1, so p(1 + 1) = p(1) + p(1) = (1 + 1) + 2Z. Now we consider two cases:

(1 + 1) + 2Z is of even order. But Z/2Z has only one nonzero element of even order, i.e 1 + 2Z. Therefore 1 is in 2Z. This means 1 = 2k for some k. But 1/2 is not an integer, a contradiction. This implies 1 + 1 is in 2Z, i.e. 1 + 1 = 2k for some k. If k is greater than 1, then 1 > 2, a contradiction. 1 + 1 = 2.

(1 + 1) + 2Z is of odd order. But the only odd divisor of 2 is 1, which means 1 + 1 is in 2Z. This is the same as the previous case.

It depends on why you give up. One possibility is that you still have high interest but get discouraged by setbacks, in which case it's not uncommon for people to get through this with something as cheesy as a daily dose of motivational videos.
A shittier possibility associated with intelligence above average is that you don't really encounter any setbacks at all but just bore easily. Like, maybe you're working through some textbooks for a couple of months and you're solving problems correctly left and right, but your interest just flatlines. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15119259
Also
>a friend recommended machine learning as a lucrative field.
kiiinda. ML is an insanely competitive field that values experimental progress over science and explainability. There is a constant race to develop novel, competitive techniques, which pushes a lot of research dollars. On the other hand, actually researching ML is an afterthought. People want to engineer systems that converge to (reasonable) answers faster and with fewer resources while running. They're content to know only as much as will tell them certain techniques are fundamentally limited, and they will wait decades before funding the research that goes into maturing these techniques into a proper theory / field.

You will make pennies in ML unless you're among the best. You'll likely lose a lot of sleep and free time if you're in it for the money. If you want to make money while being adjacent to computer science, do something like software engineering or systems CS. The former has a lot of jobs that pay handsomely compared to the work needed, and the latter has incredibly stable funding and actual, real world, impactful results, but you don't have to compromise scientific and engineering quality to stay relevant.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15116738
The problem with your proof OP is that 0.999... isn't actually a number.
To really succinctly put it, 0.999... is just a representation of 3/3rds. Because a third can't be expressed accurately in a base-ten decimal system. There's no way to write 1/3 using a decimal without losing accuracy, therefore, people just pretend that 0.333... = 1/3, even though it doesn't actually, because 0.333... is not a number, it is an infinite-length decimal used to represent the closest possible decimal equivalent of 1/3 and based on that principle: 0.999... = 1. Because 0.333... * 3 = 0.999... = 1/3 * 3 = 3/3 = 1.

Statistically speaking an event with a probability of zero is impossible, it will never happen.
An event with a probability that is infinitesimal is not impossible, but in practice very unlikely.
But then by adding up great amounts of unlikely events you get probabilities that make sense, whereas adding up great amounts of impossible events always gives you an impossible event.

>>15116738
0.999... is a poorly defined expression as "..." does not infer anything about how one is supposed to compute the digits after the first three 9's. Rather we can use a properly defined expression, the sequence defined by [math] x_n = 1- (0.1)^n [/math] or [math] y_n = \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{9}{10^k} [/math]. Of course [math] x_n = y_n [/math] exactly. [math] \lim x_n =1 [/math] and the number [math] y_\infty = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{9}{10^k} = \lim x_n = 1 [/math]

Do you believe this Turing machine halts?
I mean, think about it.
It's a matter of belief.
In other words, how are we going to arrive at a common understanding as to whether or not this Turing machine halts?
Remember, when you say
>this Turing machine halts
you're only giving yourself the axiomatic tools and inferential reasoning tools you agreed to at the outset to prove that it halts
so it's really only the Turing machines that halt from the point of view of the context of that axiomatic system, and it isn't necessarily first order logic with ZFC
So if you start with FOL-ZFC and then introduce uncomputable numbers, you're only going to get as far as FOL-ZFC uncomputable

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Okay.
Take all of the Turing machines, even the ones that don't halt, and treat them as reporting the value of the n'th digit as the Wiki article says
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computable_number
If the machine doesn't halt for any value of n, then treat the Turing machine as encoding the value 0.
Otherwise, the Turing machine encodes the value of a real number, a computable real number.
Now enumerate the Turing machines (all of them) and use Cantor's diagonalization argument to find an uncomputable number.
BOOM
I just calculated (computed) an uncomputable number.
Now put that uncomputable number at the beginning of the list, shift all of the computable numbers down one place, run Cantor diagonalization again and
BOOM
I've got two delicious charbroiled uncomputable numbers with a side of fries coming right up...

Hi /sci/, brainlet here
I don't understand the twin paradox.
According to most explanations I've found online, the reason why one of the twins experiences lees time than the other is because that twin is accelerating, and therefore there's a force acting upon them. For some reason this means that acceleration isn't relative but absolute.
This makes no sense to me. If movement through space is relative, how can acceleration not be relative? Why is the act of exerting a force suddenly cancels relativity?
Let's say I start pushing a very big rock. It's too heavy for me to move, and thus no acceleration happens, yet clearly there's a force acting upon it, does this have an impact on the rock's perception of time or not and why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15110742
Yes, consider the case of a cup of water spinning. The water will be pushed to the edges.

No matter what reference frame you are in, you will see the water being pushed to the sides of the glass, even if you are rotating around the glass at the same rate. Even if you are traveling quickly by it or towards it. The water still gets pushed to the edge.

This is one way of showing that acceleration has a universal impact that does not change due to reference frame.

Another way is examining acceleration mathematically, is noticing that you cannot just 'rotate' the 4-Vector of acceleration like you can with proper space/proper time or velocity, and so it is not Lorentz Invariant.

>>15110742
Hint: when they tell you "draw a space diagram" and then apply the Lorentz transformation, there is an hidden assumption of which frame of reference is ultimately more at rest, in the twin paradox this is usually the Earth frame. If this initial choice was different, the result would be different, say if you initially took the Earth to be moving and the rocket frame to be at rest. All inertial frame of references are equal, but some are more equal than others.
Acceleration simply moves you from one set of reference frames to another.

It is important to note that 4-acceleration has a scalar value of |γ^2| iirc so the total value of acceleration changes depending on the velocity, which is non-intuitive, since Newton's Third Law changes a bit here.

Don't be discouraged. It is hard to visualize rotations in space time.

I recommend understanding Clifford Algebra, or studying split-complex numbers, as time functions like a split-imaginary number, and the three spatial dimensions like regular imaginary numbers in Special Relativity.

While not required, it definitely gives you both English and mathematical language to discuss what is going on in terms of rotations and such.

You also get the interesting property that any space-like vector is like a bi-vector (or area) of time-like vectors, whatever that may mean.

>>15110742
If you want to understand special relativity stop thinking about inertial frames and Lorentz transformations between them. Lorentz transformations is how the subject historically developed and that is how it is still usually taught, but theoretical physicists who actually understand this stuff think about things in terms of spacetime geometry instead.

From a spacetime point of view the length of a worldline is the same thing as the proper time. In ordinary geometry the straightest path between two points has the shortest distance. In spacetime geometry the straightest (i.e. unaccelerated) path between two events has the *longest* proper time.The statement that the accelerating twin experiences less proper time is just a statement about spacetime geometry, and force never enters into this directly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15112475
It has nothing to do with particles, and it absolutely does have to do with acceleration (i.e. how much a worldline between two events differs from being a geodesic). Gravitational time dilation is a special case of this since to sit at a constant distance (in Schwarzschild coordinates) outside a black hole you need to be accelerating considerably.

If you want a toy example to consider, think about Rindler coordinates, which are just another way to describe flat Minkowski space with no matter. Rindler coordinates look very much like a "black brane," a kind of black hole with a flat event horizon that forms a plane, and there is gravitational time dilation depending on how close you are to the horizon. But the whole situation can be written in ordinary Minkowski coordinates too, and then you see that the constant distance trajectories in Rindler coordinates are really accelerating.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15116568
>the issue is how long the world-lines are, not how bent
If you have two straight worldlines that begin and end at different points, certainly they can have different proper times. But the point is that the choice of when to begin and end the worldline is not something invariant. If you look at the inertial frame of the Earth and end the worldlines of the Earth and rocket at certain values of the Earth's inertial time, then the rocket will have less proper time. If you look at the inertial frame of the rocket and end the worldlines of the Earth and rocket at certain values of the rocket's inertial time, then the Earth will have less proper time. That's the whole origin of the paradox!

The way to resolve this issue is to have the worldlines begin and end at the same point. But then the only way you can have one worldline be longer than the other is to have it "bent" i.e. accelerated.

>>15116618
You can avoid all accelerations by having a third traveler that intercepts and notices he has the same age as the outgoing twin mid-journey. It's still a fact that he will not be the same age as the Earth twin, and yet he underwent no accelerations.
The outgoing twin has to accelerate in order to go back, and that changes his frame of reference, but acceleration is not what causes the effect.

You could also have three twins, two who depart at the same time by accelerating to the same speed. One of the travelling twins stops at some point by decelerating in some way, while the other twin keeps on travelling some more, until he decelerates to a stop in the same way his other twin did, and accelerates towards home. The twin who stopped mid-way, as soon as he is intercepted by the twin travelling home, accelerates towards home in the same way as the other one did, and decelerate both in the same way as they arrive on Earth.
The twin who travelled more will have experienced more time dilation, despite the fact that both twins have experienced the same acceleration.

It's just not acceleration. It's time spent in specific inertial reference frames. Acceleration simply allows you to pass from one inertial reference frame to another.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15116804
>You can avoid all accelerations by having a third traveler
I'm going to ignore the rest of your post, which I've already addressed, and just reply to a clearer version of this idea where nothing is accelerating.

If you have three worldlines you can keep all of them perfectly straight and form a triangle where the three vertices have an absolute ordering in time. It is true that the proper time on the 'long' leg between the earliest and latest vertices will always be greater than the sum of the other two legs, and so the effect of time dilation is seen without anything physically feeling a force. Okay fine, it's a nice example.

But the path of the two small legs on the triangle is "bent," and that is why the total proper time along this path is shorter than the long leg. If you don't want to call this bent path an accelerated path that is just semantics. Also note that in this setup with a third observer that appears on the middle vertex you can never answer the question of whether the Earth or the spaceship is older because they never return to the same point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15117100
>I'm going to ignore the rest of your post, which I've already addressed
You shouldn't have. The example with two accelerating twins shows why acceleration is merely a prop, however necessary, in the thought experiment. The two twins have the same acceleration profile, yet one is affected more -- the one who travelled farthest, or for the longest time.
And indeed, acceleration on its own doesn't even figure in the calculation of proper time, how could it ever matter?
In fact, longer acceleration times for the same overall travel time *hurt* the effect, by shortening the time spent in the reference frames at max speed, and the effect is strongest when the acceleration time is minimized, because the time spent in those frames is maximized.

Also note that I don't want to "unbend" the triangle. Maybe this is the point you're getting hung up with.
There are three inertial reference frames at play that have a certain relationship between them that is independent of any acceleration, as the example with three observers (one per reference frame) shows.
If the travelling twin takes his entire journey, bent legs and all, as a rest frame, then he is wrong. Acceleration is absolute in SR, so he may only take either half of his trip as the rest frame. Once he accelerates out of it, or before he decelerates into it depending on his choice, he has to consider himself to be moving. But the acceleration is inessential to the problem, only the relationship between the three inertial reference frames is.
You may call this "semantics," what I call semantics is doing this:
>Also note that in this setup with a third observer that appears on the middle vertex you can never answer the question of whether the Earth or the spaceship is older because they never return to the same point.

posts.com:
It motivates quotients of vector spaces
You have to be stuck at a level of linear algebra below subspaces and quotient spaces
As in, you're currently taking linear algebra
Or maybe vector calculus, who cares
It's literally a quotient vector space
For example R^2 (x) R^3
Start with the vector space V_0 of formal linear combinations with real coefficients of (v,w) with v <- R^2 and w <- R^3. This is a real vector space.
Now take the subspace generated by
(xv,w) - x(v,w)
and
(x,vw) - x(v,w)
for all real x, v <- R^2, and w <- R^3
Now take the quotient of V_0 by this subspace and call it V.
That's the tensor product, in symbols V = R^2 (x) R^3.
Look in Kostrikin and Manin for details.

I think I'm done with Bill Nye. His new show sucks.
I am about halfway through Bill Nye Saves the World, and I am completely disappointed. I've been a huge fan of Bill Bye since I was ten. Bill Nye the Science Guy was entertaining and educational. Bill Nye Saves the World is neither. In this show he simply brings up an issue, tells you which side you should be on, and then makes fun of people on the other side. To make things worse he does this in the most boring way possible in front of crowd that honestly seems retarded. He doesn't properly explain anything, and he misrepresents every opposing view.
I just finished watching the fad diet episode. He presents Paleo as "only eating meat" which is not even close to what Paleo is. Paleo is about eating nutrient rich food, and avoiding processed food, grains and sugar. It is protein heavy, but is definitely not all protein. He laughs that cavemen died young, but forgets to mention that they had very low markers of cardiovascular disease.
In the first episode he shuts down nuclear power simply because "nobody wants it." Really? That's his go to argument? There was no discussion about handling nuclear waste, or the nuclear disaster in Japan. A panelist states that the main problem with nuclear energy is the long time it takes to build a nuclear plant (because of all the red tape). So we have a major issue (climate change caused by burning hydrocarbons), and a potential solution (nuclear energy), but we are going to dismiss it because people don't want it and because of the policies in place by our government. Meanwhile, any problems with clean energy are simply challenges that need to be addressed, and we need to change policy to help support clean energy and we need to change public opinion on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not really.
Good example is trying to find the initial object in the category of rotary 2-oids. A 2-oid is a quadruple (A,+,*,1) such that (A,+,1) and (A,*,1) are monoids, 1 <- A is the identity element for both, and A is rotary if (a + b) * c = (a * c) + b for all a,b,c <- A.
Homomorphism of 2-oids is a map of the domain that turns into a homomorphism for both the + monoids and the * monoids, i.e. in parallel consider the domain and codomain to be + monoids and check for homomorphism then switch both domain and codomain to * monoids and check for homomorphism again
note that + is NOT necessarily commutative, it's just another associative binary operator on A with identity element 1
at this point, I think the initial object is essentially equivalence classes of floating scrabble tiles, so the demand to go into the 3rd dimension isn't immediately obvious; and it isn't obvious that we have to do tensor product-like shenanigans with equivalence classes either...
However, categories are a huge fuckin' meme, and I can't stand this whole
>muh Working Mathematician
attitude

posts.com: Many metals have catalytic properties because they have multiple valence electrons. This allows them to bond with multiple chemicals and "loosen up" their valence shells. While in this state they can react much more freely with eachother. This is great when you're trying to do a reaction in a lab, but not so great when it's happening in living tissue. It tends to cause DNA damage and protein cross-linking, among other things. These are not a big deal in small amounts on your skin, but to a tiny bacteria it's absolutely deadly. They basically get "burnt" by the catalytic reactions and this is what kills them.
